message: I remember there was an organization that positioned itself as a talent agency for devs a number of years back. Seemed kind of an arrogant idea at the time. Seems completely innevitable now.
And perhaps after fewer beers? I'll make a note on your profile not to let you do interviews after 8:30.
Err. Sometimes I can spell inevitable. Those times are earlier in the evening, on average.

Seeing almost vitriolic reactions to the posting of a vacancy notice by a recruiter on Convore recently, and bearing in mind the current scarcity of Python talent, I wondered whether a geek-friendly recruitment agency might make a living, and how such an agency might ethically interact with the communities it served. Just a thought. Open Space?
If you can dredge up web references I'd be interested in researching their demise

Take the approach of some of the non-intrusive law firms for startups.  They go regularly to the tech events, focus on building relationships and provide a value-add other than just their services regardless of whether or not you go with them.  Basically, just be respectable service providers.
you could track down @jacobian and see what became of http://django.hiddenhires.com/
Consider me tracked down. Sadly we never got it off the ground. It's still in half-finished mode.
@jacobian This makes me very sad. How can we, the collective Django community, help?
I think the issue is that it takes more than code to run such a project, takes serious human time - so has to be approached as a business more than a software project
see http://hirelite.com/ for an example of a dev-friendly recruitment group, though they focus on startups and chatroulette-style interviews.
A generalization, naturally. Haven't worked with Grace, but she is certainly tracking the Python community fairly well and takes the time to come to PyCon.
I'm looking at spending less time on coding in future, but I'm not sure I'm ready to start up as a recruiter just yet. But it is a pity they are so justifiably ill-thought-of in the software world.
@holdenweb Not all of them (Grace Law comes to mind)
